questions.text: A 30 y/o woman presents for her first prenatal visit. She’s a Primi and is concerned about her pregnancy, as her mother experienced pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH) during her pregnancies. She is currently healthy and denies any medical problems. She is a smoker, and her BMI is 31. Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for PIH?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Smoking

Explanation:

  • Smoking during pregnancy is a serious health risk for both the mother and the baby.
  • It lowers the risk of developing hypertension during pregnancy.

 

Risk factors of Pregnancy-induced hypertension:

  • Nulliparity (Option A) 
  • Multiple Gestation.
  • BMI>30 (Option B)
  • Preexisting Conditions: Chronic hypertension.
  • Family History (Option D)
  • Race/Ethnicity: African American.
  • Age >35 years.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman is receiving magnesium sulfate for the management of severe preeclampsia. After several hours of infusion, she exhibits diminished patellar reflexes and mild respiratory depression. Her serum magnesium level is found to be 12 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate antidote for magnesium sulfate toxicity in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Calcium gluconate

Explanation:

Calcium gluconate is the antidote for magnesium sulfate toxicity. Administer 1 gram IV over a few minutes to reverse mild to moderate respiratory depression and restore reflexes.

 

Management of Magnesium Toxicity:

Immediate Actions:

  • If there is respiratory depression or cardiac toxicity, administer 10 mL 10% calcium gluconate IV over 3 minutes and discontinue magnesium sulfate.
  • If only early signs of magnesium toxicity (loss of reflexes, oliguria, mild drowsiness)- stop MgSO₄ infusion immediately and do close monitoring. No need of calcium gluconate. 

Further Steps:

  • Administer furosemide to increase urinary excretion.
  • Severe respiratory depression requires intubation and mechanical ventilation.
  • The effects of IV calcium may be short-lived if steady-state toxicity is present.

 

Sodium bicarbonate (Option A) is used primarily in cases of metabolic acidosis, not for magnesium toxicity.

Potassium chloride (Option C) is used to correct hypokalemia, not to counteract magnesium toxicity.

Magnesium citrate (Option D) is a form of magnesium used as a laxative, but it does not counteract magnesium toxicity.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 34 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with symptoms of eclampsia. The medical team decides to administer magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) for seizure prophylaxis. Which of the following correctly describes the regimen for magnesium sulfate administration ?

choices.text: Pritchard: 4 g IV, then 1-2 g/hour IV infusion.
Zuspan: 4 g IV, then 10 g IM (5 g each buttock).
Pritchard: 4 g IV, then 10 g IM, 5 g IM every 4 hours.
Zuspan: 4 g IV, then 5 g IM every 4 hours.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pritchard: 4 g IV, then 10 g IM, 5 g IM every 4 hours.

Explanation:

The Pritchard regimen recommends 4 g IV, then 10 g IM initially (5 g in each buttock) and 5 g IM every 4 hours.

Magnesium sulfate is the preferred medication for preventing seizures in pregnant women with severe preeclampsia or eclampsia.

There are two regimens to administer MgSO4: 

Regimen

Loading Dose

Maintenance Dose

Notes

Pritchard

(IV and IM)

(Option A ruled out)
  • Administer 4 g IV over 3-5 mins (20 mL of 20% MgSO4 solution)
  • Follow with 10 g of 50% MgSO4 solution: 5 g (10 mL of 50% solution) in each buttock as deep IM injection with 1 mL of 2% lidocaine in the same syringe.
  • 5g IM with 1 mL of 2% lidocaine in alternate buttocks every 4 hours; continue for 24 hours after birth or last convulsion

If convulsions recur after 15 min, give 2 g IV over 5 min (20% solution).

Zuspan

(IV only)

(Option B & D ruled out)
  • Administer 4-6 g IV over 15- 20 mins (20 mL of 20% magnesium sulfate solution).
  • If convulsions recur after 15 mins, give 2g IV (10 mL of 20% MgSO4 solution) over 5 mins.
  • 1-2 g IV infusion per hour (5 mL of 20% solution); continue for 24 hours after childbirth or last convulsion

Use an infusion pump if available. Ensure dilution to 20% solution.

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman with severe preeclampsia is receiving magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis. Her current serum magnesium level is 7.5 mg/dL. What does this indicate regarding her magnesium sulfate therapy?

choices.text: The level is within the therapeutic range for magnesium sulfate.
The level is below the therapeutic range for magnesium sulfate.
The level indicates the potential toxicity of magnesium sulfate.
The level indicates a need for immediate cessation of magnesium sulfate.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The level is within the therapeutic range for magnesium sulfate.

Explanation:

The therapeutic range for magnesium sulfate is 4.8–8.4 mg/dL (4–7 mEq/L), and a level of 7.5 mg/dL falls within this range, indicating appropriate therapeutic dosing.

 

 

Magnesium sulfate in preeclampsia and eclampsia 

MOA
  • NMDA Receptor Blockade
  • Calcium Channel Blockade: Reduces calcium influx into neurons.
  • Vasodilation: Improves cerebral blood flow and reduces cerebral edema, dilates uterine arteries, increases endothelial prostacyclin production and inhibits platelet activation.

Uses
  • Prevent seizures in severe preeclampsia and eclampsia. Prevent recurrent seizures in eclampsia.
  • Tocolytic effect (delaying preterm labor).
  • Neuroprotective: Protects the preterm baby's brain from damage by reducing the risk of cerebral palsy.

Therapeutic Range
  • To control fits, the optimum serum magnesium is 4.8–8.4 mg/dL (4–7 mEq/L). Deep tendon reflex loss at 9 mg/dL (>7 mEq/L).

C/I
  • Myasthenia gravis, hypocalcemia, moderate-to-severe renal failure, cardiac ischemia, heart block, myocarditis.
  • Avoid if alternatives are justified.

Administration and Dosage
  • Administer: Intravenously or intramuscularly.
  • Loading dose: 4–6 g IV over 20–30 minutes. (Zuspan or Sibai regimen)
  • Maintenance: 1–2 g/hour IV. Monitor urine output and reflexes.

Dosage Adjustment
  • Adjust for renal dysfunction.

Adverse Effects
  • Primarily smooth muscle relaxant: Respiratory depression (at 12 mg/dL) and cardiac arrest (at 30 mg/dL).
  • Manage with calcium gluconate 10% and furosemide if needed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents to the clinic with blood pressure readings consistently around 160/104 mmHg. She has no proteinuria or other symptoms of end-organ damage. She is diagnosed with gestational hypertension. Which antihypertensive medication is considered the first-line treatment for managing this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Labetalol

Explanation:

Labetalol is the preferred antihypertensive for managing gestational hypertension due to its safety profile and effectiveness in lowering blood pressure in pregnant women.

 

Antihypertensive Treatment During Pregnancy

First-line drugs:

Drug Class

Examples

Notes

Beta-blockers

Labetalol

Preferred. Generally safe and effective

Calcium channel blockers

Nifedipine (Option A ruled out),

Amlodipine

Safe, less BP variability compared to labetalol

Use oral nifedipine, not sublingual 
  • Labetalol commonly treats acute severe hypertension in pregnancy.
  • Initial IV dose: 10–20 mg, then 20–80 mg every 10–30 mins up to 300 mg.
  • Continuous IV infusion: 1–2 mg/min.
  • Fewer side effects than alternatives; less tachycardia.
  • Avoid in asthma, heart disease, compromised heart function, heart block, or bradycardia.
  • Methyl dopa (Option B ruled out) an alpha agonist is less effective in severe hypertension and has sedative side effects. It acts centrally and by reducing sympathetic outflow to affect a generalized decreased vascular tone.

 

Second-line drugs:

Drug Class

Examples

Notes

Vasodilators

Hydralazine (Option C ruled out)

Reserved for cases with cardiac/renal dysfunction

 

Contraindicated drugs:

Drug Class

Examples

Notes

ACE inhibitors

Enalapril, Lisinopril

Associated with severe fetal malformations
Beta blockers other than labetalol    

Angiotensin-receptor blockers

Losartan, Valsartan

Not recommended at any point during pregnancy

Diuretics are not used for controlling blood pressure it in the antenatal period. But it can be used if there is pulmonary edema.

Pre-existing Medication Management:

  • ACE Inhibitors/ARBs: Discontinue immediately upon pregnancy recognition.
  • Other Antihypertensives:
    • Mild/Moderate Hypertension: Some guidelines suggest discontinuation in the first trimester and restart if BP approaches severe range.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents at 30 weeks of gestation with BP of 170/110 mmHg and proteinuria. She is stable without evidence of end-organ damage. According to the algorithm for managing severe preeclampsia, what is the recommended management approach?

choices.text: Consider expectant management in a tertiary care centre
Monitor closely for 24 hours and discharge
Administer antenatal corticosteroids and terminate pregnancy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Consider expectant management in a tertiary care centre.

 

Explanation:

Before 34 weeks of gestation with severe hypertension (BP > 160/110mm Hg), expectant management may prolong pregnancy to improve neonatal outcomes if maternal and fetal conditions are stable.

 

Algorithm for Treating Preeclampsia

Initial Evaluation
  • Perform comprehensive maternal and fetal evaluation.
  • CBC with platelet estimate, serum creatinine, LDH, AST, ALT, and proteinuria testing.
  • Fetal evaluation: USG for estimated fetal weight, amniotic fluid volume, and fetal antepartum testing.

Decision for Delivery vs Expectant Management
  • 34+ Weeks Gestation: Deliver promptly upon maternal stabilization or with labor/prelabor rupture of membranes; do not delay for steroid administration.
  • Before 34 Weeks Gestation with Severe Preeclampsia: Consider expectant management in a tertiary care setting if maternal and fetal conditions are stable.
  • 37+ Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Opt for delivery rather than expectant management upon diagnosis.
  • Before 37 Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Managed as an outpatient; requires frequent fetal and maternal evaluation. Deliver only if specific conditions necessitate immediate intervention.

Management During Expectant Management
  • Closely monitor maternal and fetal conditions.
  • Serial laboratory testing: CBC, liver enzymes, serum creatinine.
  • Use antihypertensive therapy for acute-onset severe hypertension (systolic ≥160 mm Hg or diastolic ≥110 mm Hg).
  • Administer antenatal corticosteroids and monitor for 48 hours if delivery is indicated before 34 weeks gestation. 

Regularly check for Conditions Necessitating Delivery Regardless of Gestational Age

Maternal Conditions

Fetal Conditions
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Eclampsia
  • Suspected acute placental abruption, or vaginal bleeding without placenta previa
  • Uncontrolled severe-range blood pressure
  • Worsening renal function
  • Persistent headaches, epigastric/right upper quadrant pain
  • Visual disturbances
  • Motor deficits
  • Altered sensorium
  • Stroke
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Abnormal fetal testing
  • Fetal death
  • Fetus with low survival likelihood (lethal anomaly, Extreme prematurity)
  • Persistent reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery

Postpartum Management
  • Monitor blood pressure and symptoms post-delivery.
  • Consider NSAIDs for pain management instead of opioids.

 

Delivery is typically done at or after 34 weeks of gestation, not necessarily at 30 weeks without severe features (Option A ruled out).

 

Monitoring for fetal distress is part of ongoing management, not initial for severe preeclampsia without immediate delivery indications (Option C ruled out)

 

Corticosteroids are recommended if delivery is anticipated before 34 weeks also no need to terminate the pregnancy (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions doesn’t typically require immediate termination of pregnancy, irrespective of gestational age?

choices.text: Pre-eclampsia with severe features and stable maternal and fetal conditions

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pre-eclampsia with severe features and stable maternal and fetal conditions

Explanation:

Pre-eclampsia with severe features and stable maternal and fetal conditions may be managed expectantly with close monitoring until a more optimal gestational age for delivery is reached, typically around 34 weeks gestation.

 

Indicated delivery timing for various conditions

Condition 

Delivery timing

Chronic hypertension not on medications

38w0d – 39w6d

Chronic hypertension controlled by medications

37w0d – 39w6d

Chronic hypertension not well controlled by medications

36w0d – 37w6d

Chronic Hypertension with Superimposed Preeclampsia

37weeks

Gestational hypertension

37weeks

Pre-eclampsia without severe features

37weeks

Pre-eclampsia and Gestational Hypertension with severe features

34weeks

Pre-eclampsia with severe features, unstable or prior to viability

Delivery after maternal stabilization

Maternal Conditions

Conditions Necessitating Delivery Regardless of Gestational Age
  • HELLP syndrome (Option B ruled out)
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Eclampsia & Impending Eclampsia (Option C ruled out)
  • Suspected acute placental abruption or vaginal bleeding without placenta previa
  • Uncontrolled severe-range blood pressure
  • Worsening renal function
  • Persistent headaches, epigastric/right upper quadrant pain
  • Visual disturbances
  • Motor deficits
  • Altered sensorium
  • Stroke
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Placental abruption (Option D ruled out) 

Fetal Conditions
  • Abnormal fetal testing
  • Fetal death
  • Fetus with low survival likelihood (lethal anomaly, extreme prematurity)
  • Persistent reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery

questions.text: A 28 y/o primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presents blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg on two separate occasions, six hours apart. She has no prior history of hypertension. Her urine protein creatinine ratio is 0.4. On P/A exam, SFH is 32 cm, FHS 140/min, uterus is relaxed and she is perceiving normal fetal movements. What is the most appropriate frequency for fetal monitoring in this patient?

choices.text: Fetal heart rate (FHR) monitoring every 2 weeks
FHR monitoring weekly along with fetal surveillance.
No fetal monitoring is necessary at this time

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) FHR monitoring weekly along with fetal surveillance.

Explanation:

  • This patient presents symptoms of mild pre-eclampsia characterized by:
    • New-onset hypertension (BP >140/90 mmHg) after 20 weeks of gestation.
    • Urine protein: Creatinine ratio >0.3.
  • Fetal surveillance, including regular fetal heart rate monitoring, is essential to assess fetal well-being.
  • The frequency depends on the severity of the pre-eclampsia. In mild pre-eclampsia, weekly monitoring is generally recommended.

 

Mild pre-eclampsia

Severe Pre-eclampsia

Weekly fetal heart rate monitoring and regular prenatal checkups with a focus on:

  • Monitoring BP.
  • Proteinuria.
  • Fetal well-being
  • The Biophysical Profile (BPP) is the preferred method of fetal assessment in severe cases.
  • Parameters to be monitored:
    • NST
    • Fetal movements, breathing, fetal tone
    • Amniotic fluid volume

 

Fetal heart rate (FHR) monitoring every 2 weeks (Option A) might not be sufficient to detect early signs of fetal compromise.

 

Umbilical artery doppler (Option C) only if growth restriction is detected

questions.text: Which of the following is a well-established risk factor for the development of Pregnancy-Induced Hypertension (PIH), including preeclampsia and gestational hypertension?

choices.text: Previous pregnancy with the same partner
Exposure to chorionic villi for the first time
High levels of cell-free DNA in maternal serum

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Exposure to chorionic villi for the first time

Explanation:

  • Exposure to chorionic villi for the first time is a well-established risk factor for the development of Pregnancy-Induced Hypertension (PIH), including preeclampsia and gestational hypertension.

  • Nulliparity, meaning first pregnancy and first exposure to chorionic villi, is associated with higher risk of PIH.

  • Immunological maladaptation to paternal antigens expressed by the chorionic villi is a key proposed mechanism.

  • This risk decreases in subsequent pregnancies with the same partner due to immune tolerance.

  • Prior preeclampsia, chronic hypertension, diabetes, renal disease, autoimmune disorders are risk factors for PIH

Risk Factors for PIH

Nulliparity

First pregnancy; first exposure to chorionic villi increases PIH risk

Multifetal gestation

Increased chorionic villi quantity linked to higher risk

Maternal age & Obesity

Age > 35 years and obesity increase risk

Family history

Positive family history increases risk

Smoking (Option A)

Paradoxically associated with lower PIH risk

Biological markers

Angiogenic imbalance (sFlt-1, PlGF), endothelial dysfunction are under study, not established for clinical use

Cell-free DNA (Option D)

Investigational; no proven predictive value

  • Previous pregnancy with the same partner (Option B) actually lowers risk by inducing immune tolerance.

questions.text: A 38 y/o woman presents for her first prenatal visit. She is excited about the pregnancy but expresses concern about her family history of preeclampsia in her mother. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no history of hypertension. What is most likely recommended by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) to reduce this patient's risk of developing preeclampsia?

choices.text: Prophylactic Anti-hypertensive at 20 weeks of gestation.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Low-dose aspirin (75-150 mg/day)

Explanation: 

  • This patient’s history of pre-eclampsia in first-degree relatives is a risk factor for pre-eclampsia.
  • ACOG recommends prophylactic low-dose aspirin in such patients.

 

High-dose folic acid supplementation (Option A) is crucial in preventing neural tube defects and not pre-eclampsia.

Anti-hypertensives (Option C) are typically reserved for managing hypertension once it develops, not as a preventative measure.

Bed rest (Option D) is not recommended due to risk of thromboembolism

questions.text: A 32 Y/o woman at 28 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of persistent headaches and visual disturbances. On examination, her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, and she has 2+ proteinuria on a urine dipstick test. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Preeclampsia

Explanation: 

Based on the above scenario, the patient is most likely suffering from Preeclampsia.

 

Types of HTN in pregnancy:

Gestational HTN (Option A ruled out)
  • BP >140/90 after 20 weeks gestation at 2 separate occasions 6 hrs apart in a previously normotensive woman without proteinuria or end organ damage

Chronic HTN (Option B ruled out)
  • Pre-existing HTN presenting < 20 weeks of gestation
  • BP will not return to normal after 12 weeks of delivery 

Acute on chronic HTN
  • Chronic HTN patient with superimposed gestational HTN
  • New onset proteinuria after 20 weeks gestation

Preeclampsia (Option C)
  • BP >140/90 after 20 weeks gestation associated with:
  • Proteinuria: ≥300 mg/24 h of urine or 1+ on urine dipstick
  • Urine protein: Creatinine >0.3

Or

  • End organ damage: Platelets <1,00,000/microL; Creatinine >1.1 mg/dL; doubling of serum transaminase level; headache, visual disturbances

Eclampsia (Option D ruled out)
  • Preeclampsia + generalized tonic-clonic seizures

Delta HTN
  • Sudden rise in mean arterial pressure in pregnant women, even though being at normal levels

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman in her third trimester presents to the labor and delivery unit with a blood pressure of 165/110 mm Hg, severe headache, and visual disturbances. She reports she has been experiencing swelling in her legs and face for the past week. Urinalysis reveals proteinuria. Which of the following maternal systemic effects is the MOST likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cerebral edema

Explanation:

  • This patient’s presentation is highly suggestive of cerebral edema, a serious complication of PIH.
  • Endothelial cell dysfunction can lead to increased capillary permeability in the brain, resulting in vasogenic edema.
  • This swelling and pressure within the brain can cause neurological symptoms: Headache, vision problems and seizures.

 

Systemic effects of Pregnancy-induced Hypertension (PIH):

 

Pathophysiology

Presentation

Renal

Reduced blood flow to the kidneys causes damage to the glomeruli.

Proteinuria, renal insufficiency (increased creatinine), AKI (oliguria/anuria)(Option B)

Cardiovascular

  • Increased afterload due to hypertension.
  • Reduced preload due to diminished blood volume expansion.
  • Endothelial activation - Fluid leakage and edema.

Hypertension, decreased cardiac output, Pulmonary edema.

Neurological

  • Vasospasm leading to reduced blood flow and ischemia.
  • Increased capillary permeability in the brain.

Headaches, Visual disturbances, Seizures (eclampsia).

Hematological

  • Activation of the coagulation cascade.
  • Endothelial damage and platelet deposition.

Thrombocytopenia, Hypercoagulability (Blood clot formation) (Option D)

Hepatological

  • Reduced blood flow to the liver.
  • Systemic inflammation and oxidative stress.

Elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT), HELLP syndrome (Elevated liver enzymes and low platelets) (Option C)

questions.text:
A 28-year-old primigravida presents at 26 weeks gestation, and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated so far. Her blood pressure is measured at 150/95 mmHg on two occasions, 6 hours apart. A urine dipstick test shows proteinuria.

What is the most likely mediator involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase-1 (sFlt-1)

Explantion:

  • sFlt-1 is a potent antiangiogenic protein that is increased in preeclampsia.
  • It inhibits the action of proangiogenic factors, such as vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and placental growth factor (PlGF), creating an imbalance.

 

Factors involved in pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH)

Exposure to chorionic villi

First-time exposure to chorionic villi - High risk of PIH.

Amount of chorionic villi

Twins or a hydatidiform mole.

Pre-existing maternal conditions

Chronic hypertension, Renal disease, Obesity, Connective tissue disorders, Diabetes.

Abnormal placental implantation

Incomplete invasion of uterine vessels by trophoblasts.

Maternal immune response

Loss of maternal immune tolerance to placental and fetal antigens. Increased Th1 cell function causes decreased vascular modification.

Angiogenic imbalance

Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (sFlt-1) and Soluble endoglin (sEng).

 

PGI2 (Option B) and Nitric oxide (Option C) are vasodilators produced by endothelial cells, which are unlikely to cause vasoconstriction.

 

Although ANP levels (Option D) are elevated in preeclampsia, it is not a primary mediator of the disease.

questions.text: A 38 y/o primigravida presents at 32 weeks gestation with a blood pressure of 165/115 mmHg and new-onset proteinuria. She has a persistent headache and blurry vision. What pathophysiologic change is most likely responsible for her clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Inadequate spiral artery remodeling

Explanation:

  • This patient's presentation is consistent with severe preeclampsia, a serious complication characterized by new-onset hypertension (≥140/90 mmHg) and proteinuria after 20 weeks gestation.
  • A key underlying factor in preeclampsia is inadequate spiral artery remodelling.

Increased placental perfusion (Option A): Inadequate spiral artery remodeling leads to placental ischemia ie., placental perfusion is decreased

Decreased systemic vascular resistance (Option B): Systemic vascular resistance is increased

Suppressed maternal inflammatory response (Option C): Maternal inflammatory response is increase

questions.text: A 32 Y/o woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents with severe upper abdominal pain, headache, and visual disturbances. She has no history of hypertension or proteinuria during this pregnancy. On examination, her blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, and there is no significant proteinuria on a dipstick test. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes and thrombocytopenia. Which of the following is the initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Administer antihypertensive medication to control blood pressure.
Start magnesium sulfate infusion to prevent seizures.
Initiate corticosteroids to promote fetal lung maturity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Start magnesium sulfate infusion to prevent seizures.

Explanation:

Based on the above scenario, the patient is most likely suffering from atypical presentation of severe preeclampsia. Starting magnesium sulfate infusion to prevent seizures will be the priority.

 

Atypical preeclampsia/eclampsia:

  • It is defined as the development of preeclampsia/eclampsia without fulfilling the standard requirements.
  • Examples:
    • Early onset preeclampsia/eclampsia <20 weeks
    • Preeclampsia/eclampsia >48 hours postpartum
  • Treatment:
    • Patients with atypical presentation of preeclampsia/eclampsia should be treated as severe preeclampsia.
    • Majority of patients develop eclampsia- MgSO4 to prevent seizures is the initial management 
    • To control BP- Antihypertensives 
    • If <34 weeks- Corticosteroids for lung maturity 
    • Definitive treatment- termination of pregnancy

questions.text: A 28 Y/o pregnant woman in her second trimester at 24 weeks of gestation visits the prenatal clinic for a routine check-up. She has a history of hypertension, and her first pregnancy was complicated by preeclampsia. Which of the following is best to reduce the risk of preeclampsia in this pregnancy?

choices.text: Routine use of antihypertensive medications in the first trimester

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Daily low-dose aspirin therapy.

Explanation:

Daily low-dose aspirin therapy is most commonly recommended to prevent preeclampsia.

Preeclampsia is defined as blood pressure >140/90 mmHg with proteinuria ≥300 mg/24 h or end-organ damage after 20 weeks gestation.

 

Prevention of preeclampsia:

  • If the patient is at high risk for preeclampsia, then starting low-dose aspirin 81 mg after 12 weeks gestation is most commonly recommended to prevent preeclampsia (Option B).
  • Other interventions that decrease the risk but are not as effective as aspirin are:
    • Losing weight if obese
    • Managing high BP and diabetes (Option C ruled out)
    • Supplementation with calcium and antioxidants (Option A ruled out)
    • Regular exercise and sleep schedule
    • Low salt diet
    • Low molecular weight heparin (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 32 Y/o pregnant woman at 35 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe upper abdominal pain, nausea, and headaches. Blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg. Laboratory results reveal hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and a low platelet count. Which of the following is the definitive management for a patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Termination of pregnancy

Explanation: 

She is having severe preeclamspsia which has complicated to HELLP syndrome 

HELLP Syndrome:

Rare complication of Preeclampsia, which usually occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy

Features:

  • H- Hemolysis
  • EL- Elevated Liver enzymes
  • LP- Low Platelets

Risk factors:

  • HELLP in prior pregnancy, age >35, multiparous, history of diabetes, kidney disease

Symptoms:

  • RUQ pain, headache, blurred vision, nausea, vomiting, edema

Maternal complications:

  • Blood clotting problems, DIC
  • Kidney failure
  • Liver failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Eclampsia

Fetal complications:

  • Preterm birth
  • Growth restriction
  • Respiratory distress

Treatment:

  • Majority of patients develop eclampsia- MgSO4 to prevent seizures (Option C)
  • Antihypertensives to control BP (Option B)
  • If <34 weeks, Corticosteroids for lung maturity (Option D)
  • Definitive treatment: Termination of pregnancy (Option A)

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents with severe headache, visual disturbances, and epigastric pain. Her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg, and she has +3 pitting edema in her lower extremities. Laboratory results reveal proteinuria. All of the following are signs /symptoms of impending eclampsia except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) +3 pitting edema

Explanation:

The patient is having severe preeclampsia, and is showing signs and symptoms of impending eclampsia. Edema is not a sign of imminent eclampsia

 

The warning signs of imminent eclampsia include:

  • Blood pressure ≥160/110 on two different occasions while the patient is on bed rest
  • Proteinuria of <5 g/24 hours
  • Oliguria or anuria
  • Epigastric pain (Option C ruled out)
  • Headache and visual symptoms(Option A and B ruled out)
  • Pulmonary edema or cyanosis
  • End organ damage

 

Visual symptoms such as blurred vision, diplopia, scotomata, and amaurosis fugax are telltale signs that the patient is entering an eclamptic state from pre-eclampsia (Option B).

questions.text: Which of the following findings indicates Severe Preeclampsia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Elevated serum creatinine

Explanation:

Serum creatinine is elevated in severe preeclampsia.

 

Feature 

Non-severe preeclampsia 

Severe preeclampsia 

Systolic BP

<160 mm Hg (Option A ruled out)

≥160 mm Hg

Diastolic BP

<110 mm Hg

≥110 mm Hg

Proteinuria

300 mg/24 hours or 1+ on urine dipstick (Option B ruled out)

>5 gm/ 24 hours or 3+ on urine dipstick

Headache and visual disturbances

Absent

Present

Upper abdominal pain

Absent

Present

Oliguria

Absent

Present

Thrombocytopenia (<100000 /microL)

Absent

Present

Serum creatinine

Normal

Elevated (Option D)

Serum transaminases

Minimally elevated

Markedly elevated

Fetal growth restriction

Absent

Present

Pulmonary edema

Absent

Present

questions.text: A 37 y/o multigravida with a history of chronic hypertension, at 28 weeks twin gestation, presents with occasional headaches and visual disturbances. Her blood pressure is measured at 150/95 mmHg, and a urine dipstick test reveals significant proteinuria. Which of the following is not a risk factor for preeclampsia for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Multigravid

Explanation:

Multigravida is not a risk factor for preeclampsia. 

Preeclampsia is defined as blood pressure >140/90 mmHg with proteinuria ≥300 mg/24 h or end-organ damage after 20 weeks gestation.

 

Risk factors for preeclampsia:

  • Nulliparity
  • Age > 35 yrs (Option A ruled out)
  • BMI > 30 kg/square meter
  • Multifetal gestation (Option C ruled out)
  • Prior abruption
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Prior preeclampsia
  • Chronic hypertension (Option D ruled out)
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Molar pregnancy
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Antiphospholipid antibodies
